values: Owing to the nature of my job and the desire to keep persistent teenage noses out of my private life, this journal is Friends Locked. Please drop me a comment here if you are friending me...

A Lannister Always Spays His Pets, a photo by joely_jo on Flickr.

I really should stop finding this funny. My excuse is that I am married to a vet. Also that I am sad and there really is no hope for me...

So... for those of you who were wondering... I'm not dead. Not physically, at any rate. Imaginatively, though, almost certainly. It's been several months since I read my flist or wrote anything in my journal, and I have to say that I haven't yet decided whether I've missed it or not.

I actually feel rather guilty that I've neglected LJ for as long as I have, but I just haven't been able to summon the sort of interest in fandom things I once had. And the result of this has been a general lack of desire to write anything, read anything or otherwise contribute. 

I don't know what else to say to explain my absence... Of course I could pedal a ream of reasons about having a busy job and a happy relationship for the first time in five years, but the truth is that neither of those things have contributed any more than a little bit. The main thing has been that I just don't feel engaged with fandom stuff the way I used to. I admit that I'm quite interested in the upcoming X-Files movie, but I get most of my information on that from an independent site. The new series of Doctor Who has interested me a little, but I've missed several episodes due to other commitments and I now feel a bit withdrawn from the action. I do, however, hold out some hope that the upcoming run of episodes will give me some reason to get excited. And, finally, in terms of R/T, I just feel that I've written everything I could possibly write and would simply be recycling ideas. Which is fine, I suppose, but I suspect that an audience for that kind of thing would be pretty limited. 

And so, here we are... at the stage where I think I'm going to ban fandom from this journal and just post the odd thing about my actual life. Which will probably bore you all to death... and so, if you're friends with me for the fandom stuff, you may want to get rid of me. And I will, of course, not be offended in the slightest!
Bloody typical, isn't it? It is events like this that make me certain that religious fanaticism will be the cause of the next world war.

Oh, I have to share this with everyone...

(Sent to me in an email from a friend who is a solicitor in London - never let it be said that he takes himself too seriously!)

Lawyer - Doctor _______, before you began the autopsy, did you check for a pulse?
Witness - No.
Lawyer - Did you check for blood pressure?
Witness - No. 
Lawyer - Did you check for breathing?
Witness - No. 
Lawyer - So, then, is it possible that the subject was alive when you began the autopsy?
Witness - No. 
Lawyer - And how can you be so sure?
Witness - Because his brain was sitting in a jar on my desk. 
Lawyer - But could the subject have been alive nonetheless?
Witness - It is possible that he could have been alive and practising law somewhere, yes.

*chortle*

Sometimes it worries me how seriously some men take football. Yesterday was the staff football match. We were playing against another local school, following some kind of dare that had been issued between the PE staff and, needless to say, I have never, in all my living days, seen people take something as seriously. The Head of PE had been planning the game for about three weeks, talking about it EVERY lunchtime without fail. Staff had been cavassed to play via email, text message and other less conventional forms of nagging. The team sheet had been up on the Bulletin Board for about a week, some staff had bought new boots and shinpads for the event, and they'd thought up nicknames for each other that included things like 'The Invisible Man', 'Bite Yer Ankles Jackson', 'Speeding Bullet' and 'Paper Boy'.

By lunchtime there was so much nervous energy running through the staff room that some people couldn't sit still. It was a training day, so a few of us went out to the pub and when we returned, they were in the front playground, passing and practising penalty kicks etc... Someone had parked their car up alongside and they had 'Eye of the Tiger' and 'Three Lions' playing at volume 11...

Needless to say, I hope to God they've won because otherwise Monday will just be unbearable.

The stone rolled away... A hopeful day...

I don't often comment on political issues in this journal, but I need to make an exception today. Please let it work this time.

So, I was tagged by
larielromeniel
to do this writer's meme. Apparently, I have to name my five favourite fics that I've written, then tag five other people to do the same thing... It was an interesting exercise, actually, because I don't tend to look at my own work in an non-objective fashion like this. Three are R/T and two are DW.

WRITER'S MEME: Sometimes it's ok to pimp yourself out. Post a list of the top five favorite fics you've written, regardless of fandom or the reason you love them. This isn't about the BEST things you've written, but what you LOVE most. Then tag five other people to do the same.

Nine Moments That Lead To Forever - A familiar format for me. I seem to do short and sweet much better than I do long and multi-chaptered. I like this fic because I love seeing snapshots of bigger pictures.

My Rose - The first fic I ever wrote for DW. Told from Mickey's POV and therefore something that was a challenge to write in itself, as I feel most comfortable with Doctor or Rose POV. Oh, and Mickey rocks.

He Who Dares - Probably the fic I'm most proud of. It just gels together for me. I loved writing it.

Conviction - An overlooked fic of mine, but one I love nonetheless. It's dark and angsty to begin with but has a real message of hope and love.

Playing Your Cards Right - I don't write humour very often, because I worry that I'm not actually funny. However, I love this piece cos it's got Sirius in it and I actually reckon I've nailed him pretty well. And, of course, he's so much fun to write.

So, Pugno Mortem isn't in there, Stages isn't in there and neither is Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas. Eh. What does that tell you? Either that I'm a harsh judge or I've got really weird taste in fics, I suppose!

And now I tag

,

The passing of time on a Saturday evening can seem terribly slow, especially when there's nothing on the telly except Tom Cruise butchering one of your favourite science-fiction books ever, your fanfics are all either finished or stalled, there's nothing to read that you haven't either read before or firmly believe is a pile of over-rated rubbish and none of your DVDs seem appealing. I'm so bored even the thought of Toby Stephens doing dark and brooding in Jane Eyre is uninteresting.

*sigh*

Think I'll go and make another cup of tea...

Nicked from , because I'm bored and I need to write more and my Muse has deserted me...
You Should Be a Film Writer
You don't just create compelling stories, you see them as clearly as a movie in your mind. You have a knack for details and dialogue. You can really make a character come to life. Chances are, you enjoy creating all types of stories. The joy is in the storytelling. And nothing would please you more than millions of people seeing your story on the big screen!
What Type of Writer Should You Be?

So I was searching around one of the old sites I used to frequent when I was a fan of ER and whilst re-reading one of the threads I found myself beginning an internal debate...

In every fandom I've been involved in shippers have been treated like foolish, idiotic, squeeing fangirls with nay more than a pair of brain cells to rub together. It seems that if you express a liking for a particular relationship dynamic, there's always somebody there to slap you in the face and tell you you're being a romantic featherweight.

So my questions are these: Why is it that when there is a hint of a relationship portrayed in a series or book, we get legions of people slapping it in the face? Why was Rose Tyler considered weak for crying her heart out after she was separated from the Doctor? Why was Doug Ross considered weak for walking away from Carol after Ricky died? Why is Tonks considered weak for being depressed by Remus's denial of their love in HBP? 

Why is it so difficult to believe that fictional characters should have real human emotions and be affected by them in same way that any of us are? It seems as if some people want their fictional characters not to have the flaws and features that make us human, that they want them to always make the perfect choices and never make mistakes, over-react or, for that matter, under-react... Because when they do display an iota of realistic, believable behaviour to the stimuli of grief, love, sadness, loss and all those other utterly powerful and compelling emotions, people detract the characters and demean those people who support them. And that's what I find so confusing. How can believing in the true nature of human reactions, be they good, bad or indifferent be considered weak or pathetic or fangirly? 

To me, fiction is not fiction if you cannot recognise in it elements of real life and facets of human nature.

I've been thinking a lot about recs recently. For lots of reasons, but I won't bore you with the details. Well, not all of them, at any rate! ;)

A little while ago, I'm told it was theregoesyamum did a thing called The Circle Of Love. For any of you who didn't see it, it was a post where she picked six stories to rec based on nothing but her own personal preference. I was one of those recs *hee!* and the idea intrigued me.

There are loads of fics I enjoy in my daily wanderings through fandom, but it takes something really 'wow' for me to add a fic to my memories. Consequently, I don't have a lot of memories (although I've just realised exactly HOW that statement would sound to a non-LJ-speaking person!). But still, I felt the Circle Of Love was a fab idea and so I intend to pass it on. Thing is though, I would really like to see other luffly f-listers take up the Circle and PASS IT ON, PASS IT ON! McGonagall was right - we DO need a little more love in the world.

So, what should you do? Well, you should pick six fics you consider to be outstanding examples of writing, characterisation, smuttiness or whatever particular thing floats your boat... BUT, they should be under-appreciated in some way.

Here be mine... If you haven't already, I urge you to read these fics, and if you love them like I did, comment!

The Longing by bumblebean (HP R/T - PG-13) This was utterly beautiful, and I think my heart broke with the last few lines.
Destination Unknown by claireydid (HP R/T - PG-13) One of those 'wow' pieces I was talking about earlier. Very powerful.
A Garden Eastward by le_parapluie (HP R/T - 'strong' PG-13) Short but perfect and extra marks awarded for using the prompt 'bitten apple' in the way it was intended to be used.
Reduction by jadeddiva (HP R/T - R)  This is the most recent update, but you need to read the whole story through the links. A very honest portrayal of the character of Tonks.
Shard by centaurea_m (DW Ten/Rose - PG) Powerful emotions, powerful characterisation... just, er, powerful all over, really.
Dishevelled by rabid1st (DW Ten/Rose - R) Ten as a real alien, and hell, if Doctor sex is this interesting, then I volunteer... (like I wouldn't anyway... *sigh*)

While in the depths of fic writing and editing last night, I had a crisis of confidence. I have a fic that has taken me a little while to write that I was initially happy with, but now feel like it's utter shite. It's more of a light-hearted piece than my normal standard and I think that perhaps this is the problem. Whenever I choose to write in a more light-hearted style (usually because I'm worried about appearing like a 'Fetch me some rope, I can't take it anymore!' type writer)I get this feeling, and it's usually reflected in the number of reviews the piece gets. So I thought I'd ask you guys what style I should stick to when I write... or if you think I should just keep ringing the changes and persevering...

<lj-poll-708769>

Of course, comments are appreciated too, so long as they're helpful! ;) Cheers!
Just a quick heads up to anyone who might not have been involved in rt_challenge. I've just posted links to the entries I made for this challenge on my fic journal, otherwise known as joelywrites.

So, I thought I'd post a Smut!Update.

How's it going?

Well first off, it was going PANTS. And I mean that in the Wallace and Gromit sense of the word, so don't get any ideas... ;)

Initially, I tried writing a PWP Moment In Time kind of piece, but then I stopped myself I thought about how much I hate reading PWP's where the sole aim is quite obviously to get Remus and Tonks into bed and shagging asap... So, then I tried to think of how I could write something where the sex was a bit more of an important part of the plot. And then I stumbled upon an idea. (forgive the lengthy explanation, but I swear it's necessary!)

I loathe with a burning passion fics about multicoloured werepups. They drive me bonkers. I don't have a degree in genetics, but I know enough to be damn sure that lycanthropy couldn't possibly be inherited. It could be a blood toxin in the same way as HIV, but that would mean Tonks would catch it as well, and I don't buy into that camp either. So, in my humble opinion the idea of multicoloured werepups is completely ridiculous.

It is also such a rarity to see a R/T fic where pregnancy and or babies are tackled with any sense of reality. Personally, I find the idea that Remus would agree to a baby on a whim as bizarre considering his quite obvious commitment issues... the only way you could realistically get around that would be to show them several years down the line in a real relationship a la Portkey's 'Simply Red' fic. But even then I struggle with the idea that Remus wouldn't have issues about becoming a father. And Tonks is a young professional as well, and no matter how you look at it, working mums are more likely to be older before they have children. So, to me, any fic where R/T become parents has to be set a few years into the future... which brings with it its own set of problems because the characters are going to have different lives from the ones we've been shown in canon and to some degree, they are going to have changed a bit too... Eek.

I've always wanted to hit back at the dozens of multicoloured werepups fics I've read and actually write a pregnancy story where things were a bit more realistic, and not so long ago I decided to do this. I wrote about 500 words, then stalled and for ages, the fic sat on my hard drive gathering metaphorical dust. I just couldn't get the story to fit around all the parameters I've talked out above. Then, a few days ago, it hit me when my mind was wandering at work... hit me so badly that I was desperate to get home to put my ideas down. This was where the Smut could be...! And hallelujah, it wouldn't have to be OTT inyerface with ostrich feathers n kinky knickers sex either! It could be real sex between two people in a real relationship and the plot... well, the plot could be the pregnancy story I'd always wanted to write.

So I have been busy writing the rest of that story and it's actually coming on okay. As some of you know, I'm never very confident about my fics before I post them, and this one is no different, but I'm pleased because in one fic I've managed to tackle two of my Writing Aims With R/T. And it's quite satisfying. I don't know when I'll be finished, but I'm already thinking there could be scope for a sequel... So, we'll see.

Nicked from jadeddiva... Let me know what you think...

 

Johari Thingummy

(a personality test for your friends, for those of you who haven't seen her explanation)

Gee, I'm loving this whole rt_challenge thing!

I started off with the sole intention of writing a fic based around one of the prompts. As soon as I saw the prompts, I was overcome with delight at one of them in particular, and in a frenzy of creativity, poured out my fic in about half a day. Feeling quite satisfied, I sent it off to my beta-reader and sat back, calm in the knowledge that I had something to contribute...

But then, everyone started posting loads and loads of wonderful, but very short, stuff. Drabbles, dozens of them, with the odd ficlet thrown in for good measure. In fact, I don't think anybody has yet posted anything much over 1,000 words. And my fic clocks in at over 7,000 words. Eek.

Quietly, I started to panic, imagining that people would hardly have the patience to sit through my mini-novel... So, I thought, maybe I won't post my fic. Maybe I'll write a couple of drabbles and just leave it at that. I sat this morning writing them, and while they're okay, I just can't get my head around this hardly-any-words thing... I can never say what I want to say, because I'm always using ten words instead of two.

So, now I'm in a quandry. Do I post the drabbles, which I think are pretty mediocre, or should I just bite the bullet, resign myself to my terminal verbosity and post the fic? Hmmm...

Well, I've done it, I've gone and posted my new fic on my new journal... *sigh of relief* At the moment, it's all a bit confusing for me, so please bear with me while I take everyone on a journey of linkage through my main journal. I promise I will get myself better organised for next time... ;)

Faith

Ah. Have finally recovered myself from New Year... Oh dear, I was very drunk. :) Something to do with a cocktail in The Arc in Leeds called Trailer Trash which had half a pomegranate on the top filled with vodka and set alight. Mmm. It was too nice, and so deceptively filled with alcohol, damnit... Have tried to find the recipe on the Net but no luck.

And of course, it wouldn't have been a night out if I hadn't ended up flat on my face... But I was too smashed to care by that point. I think I need to find a man who'll be impressed by my lack of balance or else who doesn't mind being embarrassed by a girlfriend who has an awful tendency to make an arse of herself. And I wonder why I'm single... Meh. 

And today... Well today, I have spent today reading lots of new fics, being bloody impressed by my Ikea-Bedside-Table-Assembling Skills, tidying my filthy pit of a house, listening to lots of music very loudly and totally loving the rt_moonlighting comm. Congrats to all the talented peeps who put that together - it looks fabulous. And to any one else on my f-list who hasn't got their arses over there, do so now, please...

So, after seeing GoF for the third time the other night, I have a silly Christmas question... And cos I'm feeling silly, I would love some silly answers from people...


What would Voldemort want for Christmas?


Now, obviously, if you just treat this as canon/boredom then the answer is Harry Potter, tied to a stake and wandless, or similar... but I'd rather be silly, so I thought of these:

A waltz with Neville...
A better wand than the pants one they gave me in the Gof film...
A nose-job...

So, go on, be silly!

And Happy Christmas to all!

It is hard to believe, because I'm normally such a cynical old cow, but I'm in a good mood. And this is partly down the events of the last few days, which I will summarise briefly for those of you who are interested...

Thursday brought Activities Day at school, and the mammoth efforts of organisation us teachers have to coordinate in order for the day to run smoothly. Whoever invented Risk Assessments I think should be made to be the victim of their vivid imaginations... I mean, come on... 'Select the right size bowling balls to be sure that fingers do not get stuck in the holes' and 'Pupils should wear warm clothes when skating but no very long scarves which can get caught up on things'. My opinion of these sorts of things is that if you can't work out to check whether your fingers fit in the holes of the bowling ball before you shove your fat little sausages in then perhaps you are not quite ready to be allowed out into the real world at all. But, needless to say, there were no tragic accident involving scarves or anything else. I very much enjoyed Narnia and I was quietly impressed by the numerous battle scenes which miraculously had people being killed left right and centre but without a drop of blood to be seen. If you have kids, I advise that you take them to see it. If you don't, I suggest you only go if you can access your Inner Child. 

Friday was the Last Day Of School and I think I was more relieved than the kids! Somehow, this term has completely worn me out, to the point where I was seriously thinking about pulling a sickie, and I'm the sort of conscientious person who would be eaten up with guilt if I did something like that. Of course, it was a typical final day with games, DVD's and lunch out at the pub, so it was quite pleasant. The one moment of pain was during our Year assembly in the afternoon, when the Year 9 band loudly murdered American Idiot on the stage and I had to stand on the sidelines clapping my hands unenthusiastically. But, at least they seemed to enjoy themselves...

My friend came up from Kent to stay with me this weekend, and it was great to see her. Because we live so far away we hardly ever get to see one another and I really enjoyed myself all weekend. We went to Lincoln and had a very civilised afternoon shopping and admiring the cathedral, castle and remarkably tasteful christmas lights. In the evening, we went out with some of my other friends for a Chinese meal and a few drinks. Sunday gave us coffee at the local posh hotel, then a second viewing of GoF (cos she's just about the only friend I have who appreciates Potter) and dinner in Pizza Hut. It was all very fun and I was sorry to wave her goodbye, because I know I won't see her probably for another year.

I'm also hoping to get one of my fics up in the next few days as I've got the distinct feeling that I've read it through more times than is probably healthy. I'm really excited by 's fic rec site idea. It's something I feel the Lupin/Tonks/HP universe has needed for a while now. I know there are other fic rec sites out there and they are very good, but I do think they tend to focus on the older, more established authors. There are a lot of people I've come across in this fandom who never read anything but the Old Masters and it really depresses me, because there are some really good new authors out there... it's just that now you have to weed through the trash to find them. If there was a fic rec site where talented new authors could be championed I'm sure it would go some way to countering this situation. So, go ! You have my complete support... for what it's worth!

Ooh. Guess I'd better write number three...! ;) Seriously, though, that sort of advice is really helpful stuff, so cheers, me dears. 

Anyway, today I came over all Jamie Oliver and baked a cake!

<lj-cut text="Joely's Totally Excellent Cake Baking Adventure!"> 

But, it was something of a disaster. Once I'd made it, I disappeared off to write some Christmas cards and when I returned to said cake, it was still looking rather flat and unimpressive. Consulting the picture in Jamie's book of a fluffy, perfectly risen masterpiece, I decided that it probably needed more time in the oven, so I left it a bit longer, poured myself a glass of wine and went back to my Christmas cards. This time when I returned, the cake was still flat, but was now a good deal browner than the one in the picture. I took it out of the oven, turned it out and it promptly broke into three bits. 

By this point I was starting to feel like Bridget Jones cooking the Blue Soup. I stared in frustration at my effort. Then, I had a brainwave. I would piece it back together, then seal it together with some icing. Which I did. Only the icing didn't really do the job properly and the cake it still in three bits, it just has an interesting layer of icing covering it now. I was going to post a picture of it for you all to laugh at but unfortunately I'd not bothered to close the camera shutter and it is dead as a dodo in the battery department... Oh well.  

Having said all that, it tastes okay. I'm eating a bit now and it goes down quite nicely with the wine. However, I don't think Jamie Oliver is going to be calling round asking for my advice...

</lj-cut>

Today has been a day of losing things and general forgetfulness. In the course of the day I have...

1. Lost my classroom keys, twice.
2. Misplaced an OHT of a poem I needed for a class this afternoon then found it again, oddly, in the loos.
3. Left my car unlocked until lunch-time.
4. Forgotten to pick up my pen from the computer room.

And then, quite interestingly,

5. Locked two children in the computer room because I'd forgotten I'd left them working in there!

I think I should just have stayed in bed this morning, although at least I've been able to see the funny side of the last one... but, unfortunately, so has everyone else I work with and the 'don't worry, she's blonde' comments have already started up again. And just when I thought I'd convinced everyone that I was doing so much better this year!

I sat in on an Animations lesson as well this morning, which was frankly absolutely hilarious. I animated a present changing colour and spinning and then a little green man dancing. It was crap of course, and far inferior to the stuff the kids manage to produce!P>

It was fun though, and I so wish there had been these sorts of subjects when I did my GCSEs. I think I would have had much more enthusiasm for my education if I could have studied Animations instead of Latin.

Well, what has happened to me this weekend...? Trials and tribulations, I'll tell you. In fact, it frankly has been a pretty frightful experience all round. The only way I can think to purge my brain is to write it down, so here goes...

<lj-cut text="Trials and Tribulations">

Friday...
  It was Christmas Fayre night in Brigg, my hometown, tonight. The Christmas Fayre in Brigg is a tacky, hideous event where the World and his Wife descend on the market square to pay 50p for a ticket to win a ridiculously over-large stuffed Polar Bear, get sugar highs from toffee apples and candy floss, and stand in butt-freezing-off weather watching a brass band made up of two trumpets, a tuba, a tone deaf trombonist and a fat guy playing a triangle. Oh, and then there's the lights, which are nothing if not spectacular, and they are definitely not spectacular. 
  This year was no different. I was dragged, kicking and screaming, by the parents down into the town centre, cajouled by such phrases as 'it's good to be part of your community' and 'come on, i'll buy you a drink'... Actually, it was the last one which proved to be the deciding factor, but we don't say anything to the parents. And of course the event proved to be just as traumatic as it usually is. This time, there was even a choir of little old ladies singing out of tune renditions of O Come All Ye Faithful and Mistletoe and Wine. It was the sort of stuff they would torture cats with. I wandered around with my parents for a while, but I think they finally got the message I was bored out of my mind when I mentioned for the fifth time that it looked surprisingly warm and cosy in the pub. 
  The pub was exploding with people, so the best we could do was to perch precariously on the very edge of one of the window seats and sit glumly making conversation. A little after 8:30, we trudged home in what was now pissing rain to watch Have I Got News For You and eat a curry. 
  Bollocks to community spirit is what I say.

Saturday...
  Last week my mother suggested to me that we go Christmas shopping together on Saturday. Now, history has taught me that shopping with my mother can be quite a pleasurable experience. Often, she feels overcome by some form of motherly love and likes to express it by whipping out her credit card to buy me something I have made a passing comment about. So, I got up early and trotted down eagerly to meet her only to find that she had decided to invite my father to come along with us. Very quickly, my genteel and possibly profitable shopping trip with my Mum turned into Daddy's Day Out. Within the space of five minutes, he had changed our destination, decided that he would drive, and suggested that he and Mum went looking at antiques while I wandered round the shops on my own. Needless to say, I was less than impressed by this turn of events.
   When we duly arrived in the chosen venue, he and Mum disappeared and I was left to look round Marks and Spencers on my own. I quickly tired of shopping and decided to find myself a cafe to get a cuppa in, but as I was walking along the road, observing how the drains were quite blocked and there were several large puddles spreading most of the way across the road, one of those fucking enormous Chelsea Tractor 4x4's wheeled around the corner going way faster than it should have been, surged straight into one of the puddles and effectively drenched me from mid-waist to toe. I was so shocked I couldn't even manage to summon the clarity of thought to give the driver a two-fingered salute as he screeched off into the distance. 
  Then, as I was standing, pissed off and wet through, Mum called me to say that she'd had an argument with Dad and was coming to find me. Before I really knew it, I was playing ping pong ball between my fighting parents, relaying messages because they weren't talking to one another, and trying to ease the tension by cracking pathetic jokes. In the end, though, all my efforts proved fruitless, because the result was that both of them ended up focusing their irritation on me. 
  If you ask me, you can't win.

Sunday...
  This day was considerably better than the previous two. I decided to go down and get my car valued to see if I could afford to get it changed. The place was practically deserted, except for a pimply youth in a jacket two sizes too big for him, who, much to my chagrin, started to walk purposefully towards me. However, as he got closer, and eagerly thrust his card at me, I realised that he was the son of one of the posh women who used to swan about outside my prep school bragging about how bright and gifted their brats were. Let's just say that it made a smile cross over my face when it dawned on me that he was flogging cars for a living and being made to wear a company uniform that gave him a passing resemblance to a kid wearing his dad's clothes. 
  Then, I met up with an old friend from grammar school with whom I was finally going to see GoF with. The movie was, I felt, admirable in its condensing of a two and and half inch thick book into two and a half hours of film. I enjoyed Daniel Radcliffe's performance, but was disappointed by Mad-Eye Moody. I thought Voldemort was impressively scary (particularly as the little girl sitting in front of us had to be taken out by her father when he appeared), and while I worked hard to get past the feeling that David Tennant would suddenly conjure a tardis from the sidelines to make his escape, I never quite mastered it, even with the slightly worrying tongue-flicking thing. 
  After this film, I'm interested in how they will deal with the multi-character cast in OotP. I have the horrible feeling that they will end up cutting some of my favourite characters...

</lj-cut>

So, as you can see, quite an eventful weekend. Just two more weeks to go at school I keep telling myself... although this term feels like it's gone on for forever and I am so tired that I can't be bothered to even care. And the worst part of it all is that I've got to go and watch King Bloody Kong next Thursday with a gaggle of Year Nine brats who will be no doubt chucking popcorn at each other, drinking vast quantities of that vividly blue coloured iced concoction and then getting hyperactive and uncontrollable. 

God. I've just realised that I sound like such a grump... So, I'm going to shut up.

Well, I tried to do the Book meme that has appeared in the last few days, but my sodding lj was having none of it. Everytime I tried to update, I got the same error message... BML block 'XML' has no close. I haven't a clue what this means, so if anybody has any brainy solutions, I would be v. pleased. 

In the meantime, I thought I'd list ten books I have read and enjoyed in the adult world, ten in children's literature, then ten I have always meant to read. I excluded anything that probably wouldn't be considered 'literature' by boring high-brow types... so no Star Trek or X-Files books, I'm afraid :(

<lj-cut text= "Books">

Read

1. Catch-22, Joseph Heller (changed my life, I think)
2. To Kill A Mockingbird, Harper Lee (ditto above)
3. His Dark Materials, Philip Pullman
4. Sense and Sensibility, Jane Austen
5. Wuthering Heights, Emily Bronte
6. A Christmas Carol, Charles Dickens 
7. Jane Eyre, Charlotte Bronte
8. Good Omens, Terry Pratchett and Neil Gaiman
9. Notes From A Small Island, Bill Bryson (makes me roar, just cos he's so damn right)
10. The Diary of Bridget Jones, Helen Fielding (there's nothing quite like Bridget)

Children's Literature

1. Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, J. K. Rowling (well, she had to be there somewhere!)
2. His Dark Materials, Philip Pullman
3. Holes, Louis Sachar (the greatest interwoven narrative I've ever read)
4. The Amulet of Samarkand, Jonathan Stroud (a hoot!)
5. Coraline, Neil Gaiman (scary shit for little kiddies)
6. The Hobbit, J. R. R. Tolkien
7. How I Live Now, Meg Rosoff
8. Witch Child, Celia Rees
9. Matilda, Roald Dahl
10. The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time, Mark Haddon (very revealing, certainly made me think)

Always Mean To Read

1. The Catcher In The Rye, J. D. Salinger (picked it up loads of times, but have never got past the first ten pages)
2. Tess of the D'Urbervilles, Thomas Hardy
3. A Suitable Boy, Vikram Seth (oh, it's just soooo long!)
4. A Secret History, Donna Tartt (cos everybody keeps saying how good it is...)
5. The Picture Of Dorian Gray, Oscar Wilde
6. Trainspotting, Irvine Welsh
7. Little Dorritt, Charles Dickens 
8. Le Morte D'Arthur, Thomas Malory 
9. Angus, Thongs and Full-Frontal Snogging, Louise Rennison (just cos it's supposed to be the kids version of Bridget Jones)
10. Girl With A Pearl Earring, Tracy Chevalier

</lj-cut>

Uh. Have had a pounding headache all day that has refused to leave me despite being hammered with mega-strength drugs, kool n soothe strips and about ten glasses of water. So, now I've resorted to drinking whisky. At least then they'll be a reason for me having a headache...

Year Seven were complete little shits today. I swear kids are getting more immature with every year that comes up... They do my head in. They whinge. They whine. They can't sit still. They need clarification of every bloody detail. They don't listen. I chose SECONDARY education because I DIDN'T want to be dealing with this kind of irritation on a daily basis. I can deal with it when kids swear, fight and throw chairs across the classroom. I can't deal with it when they repeatedly ask to go to the loo, want to know whether it's okay if they turn over the page in their exercise books and whinge about some fractured fingernail they incurred when Mr. Barlow made them play rugby and they didn't want to. Grr.

Have also just nicked The Independent off my parents to read the new Bridget Jones columns. Have only sporadically managed to organise myself to buy the paper to read these, but boy did I get a shock when I read today's column. Bridget's pregnant! And she's just told Mark Darcy that it's not his baby, it's Daniel Cleaver's! OMG. That can't happen. It's wrong, wrong, wrong, I tell you!

Oh, I am so tired today. I feel as if someone's replaced all of my brains with cotton wool. There are a dozen or more things I should be doing... examples include ironing some clothes so that I will actually have something suitable to wear for work tomorrow, bringing the bin in from the street so it doesn't look as if I've abandoned my home, cleaning the mank out of the upstairs plughole or addressing the pile of marking that is toppling precariously on my desk. 

But I'm not doing any of those things. I'm sitting on the sofa drinking tea, eating chocolate and watching insects mating on David Attenborough's latest nature expose. I am quite shocked actually, by the brutality of mating insects. Now I know where that old Space song 'The Female Of The Species' comes from. Did you know there are absolutely loads of female insects who eat their partners once they've finished with them? Now, I've come across certain men with whom I feel eating them post-coitally would have been an appropriate way to deal with their dickheadedness, but to do so to every partner seems a trifle mean. But then, I suppose insects don't have our hang-ups... and I guess it certainly deals with the soccer-widow/farting in bed/leaving dirty socks on the bedroom floor issues that come with a long-term relationship... ;)

Anyway, I should probably get an early night... at least then I maybe won't have to lie in bed cursing at the alarm-clock tomorrow morning.
So, Imelda Staunton is Dolores Umbridge. Damn. I was plugging for Terry Jones.

Well, first of all, Happy Thanksgiving to all the Americans I know... Even though I'm burning with jealousy at the fact that I had to go to work today and my diet will continue for at least another month. Bah. 

And then... well, I'm just sitting on my bum in my f-ing freezing house dressed up like some kind of odd version of the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man seeking for entertainment of any kind because I am soooooo bored I'm starting to count the pattern on the wallpaper. But then, I'm looking forward immensely to taking advantage of extended drinking hours in good ol' Blighty this Friday night. Feel a few pints down the Yarborough Hunt will be a suitable celebration. Though of course, I shall be eminently sensible in my alcohol consumption and make sure I am in no way embarrassingly drunk or in need of help to climb the step to get out... ;)

Am just about finished with a fic at the moment... and hell, even I'm shocked by how surreal and deep it is. Which could be a good thing or it could mean I could be force-feeding people another turkey before Christmas...!  

Anyway, I'm off to watch Little Britain now. *computersaysnooooo!*

It is very cold here. I think the proverbial brass monkey lost his tail sometime on Saturday night and has not seen it since...

So, I don't often have a life, but when I do, I make damn sure it's good. Last week, I got invited to Sheffield to see an old uni friend I haven't seen in ages. She's just bought herself a house in the city and was mad keen to show it off, so I deigned to give her the joy of my presence... And wasn't it a joy!

<lj-cut text= "Joy">

Am so very very tired. Spent all night on Friday drinking my little socks off in Sheffield with a mate. Ended up really rather squiffy indeed after who knows how many cocktails. (flirted like mad with the sexy barman and got myself a unique concoction with raspberries and mint in it... twas v. yummy!) Got in to my mate's house about four in the morning, fell asleep in my clothes on the sofa, but was woken up just four hours later by the next door neighbours who were very thoughtfully having cavity wall insulation put in at 8AM on a Saturday. Thought about running out into the street and screaming 'Shut The Fuck Up!', but figured it would probably have little effect other than to make me seem like a barkin mad fruitcake.

Once the mind-numbing noise had set up it didn't stop, so I got up, ate more toast than is probably necessary, (alcohol does that to me) then went to Meadowhell. I tried to persuade my mate to go and see GoF, but she was unrelenting in her 'Potter is for geeks' narrow-mindedness, so I gave up and resigned myself to the fact that I will have to wait to see it. Still, that hasn't stopped me reading all the reviews and whoring every little piece of information I can find. From what I've learned, I've practically seen the film anyway! 

Spent a bit of money, then went out again in the evening. Was still feeling like someone had pulled my brain out through my nose and threaded it back in through my ear, when my mate suggested we go for a dance. This was all fine and dandy, but then while returning to the bar to top up my whisky, I tripped on the floor where someone had spilt their beer and broke the heel clean off my shoe. I was thoroughly pissed off and demanded that we go home immediately, so we started walking to the taxi rank, me in bare feet, jumping like an insane version of Jimini Cricket because the pavement was frosted over. 

Then, just as we'd walked about three hundred yards in this fashion, two blokes caught up with us. We'd never met them before in our lives, but quite unbelievably, one said to me, "You look like you could do with a lift..." I pouted angrily, thinking he was insulting me, but then, quite unexpectedly, he added, "Allow me...", then proceeded to pick me up and carry me to the taxi rank! Ha! Chivalry is NOT dead! But, the worst thing of this is, I was so bloody shocked out my head that I never asked him for his number...! 

Doomed, I tell you, doomed! To wander the earth looking for my chivalrous chappie once again! ;(    

</lj-cut>

I'm off on one now. You may just see steam issuing from my journal pages...

<lj-cut text="RahGrizzleGrrRant">

I am pissed off. I have just had a story rejected from a shall-remain-nameless fanfic website for the second time for totally ridiculous reasons. Intermixed with my wrath and anger is a healthy dose of disheartened indignation. They market themselves as being a big-up 'elite' fansite, where only the very best authors get their work published, but from what I've seen they apply their rules very sporadically. For example...

They claim they are only interested in fics that match with canon, yet they publish numerous stories where Ginny and Draco are secretly madly in love... Call me thick, but I don't see where that fits with canon.

And...

They state they are interested in ensuring that all fics have no grammar/spelling/punctuation errors, and in the same day, a fic is published to their website with no fewer than twenty-three grammar and punctuation mistakes. 

I know there are probably loads of people who love this site, but at the moment I need to vent. I did love the site myself to begin with (a welcome relief from some of the total trash that can be found on the web), and I suspect this is probably why everything has pissed me off so much. 

Every year, I mark around fifty GCSE Original Writing assignments, and in my time I have seen the good, the bad and the ugly as sin. I know I'm not a perfect writer, but I also know I'm not totally fucking pathetic, and I've seen stories on the site in question that I wouldn't have even marked with a pass grade. I believe that if you're going to champion yourself as an upholder of high standards, you should at the very least make sure you apply those standards fairly and consistently.   

But, you know, I don't care. Fuck them. It won't stop me writing. I enjoy it, I like trying to make myself better, and I believe in providing people with constructive criticism so they can make themselves better, not simply dismissing them out of hand with little reason or explanation.
</lj-cut>

Ah. That feels better! :)

I am currently watching an adaptation of Macbeth on the Beeb that is set in a London Restaurant with Macbeth and Duncan as award-winning chefs. They're trying to make things like cooking chicken breasts scary. And the witches are binmen... wrap your brain around that one.

Hm. So. Spent all day today running around like a blue-arsed fly around school searching for a set of textbooks, becoming more and more hairless as the day went by and the books remained elusive, only to find them, at 3.45, right in front of my nose in the cupboard I'd looked in about twenty bloody times. Decided that the best way to make myself feel better was to get writing... but I have run into a slight problem. I don't have a blinking clue what to write about. No ideas at all. Just a relentless grey fog churning around in my wee brain pissing me off. Briefly entertained the thought of writing about werepups, but it's all been done before. Grr. 

So, I'm thinking, maybe I should stop slagging them off and adopt the methods of the people who wrote the Macbeth adaptation and put Remus and Tonks in some kind of whacked out setting... The lunar landscape, perhaps. Now that would be intriguing... ;)
